seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Broccoli Pasta
body:
Broccoli may seem to be the old kale, however, it is not a vegetable we should be replacing. Broccoli has a whole different action on the body when compared to our other leafy friends, and it's one of the world's healthiest foods.
Serves: 2

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

2 cups raw pasta 
1 head broccoli, (chopped into large pieces) 
1 cup green peas, frozen 
¼ leek, roughly chopped (even the green part) 
1 cup parsley, roughly chopped 
Olive oil 
Salt and pepper, to taste

Directions

Cook the pasta until medium or undercooked. (Follow the pasta cooking instructions.) 
Add the rest of the ingredients and cook until the pasta is al dente. 
Drain and serve with fresh parsley and a splash of olive oil.
teaser: Broccoli has a whole different action on the body when compared to our other leafy friends, and it's one of the world's healthiest foods.

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Broccoli, Spinach & Pea Soup
body:
Popeye was so onto it with his spinach! This simple green leaf is one to not miss on the dinner plate. Spinach has been shown to be cell protective, helping to reduce your risk of chronic diseases such as cancer.
Serves: 4

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

1 leek or onion 
3 garlic cloves, roughly chopped 
2 stalks celery, roughly chopped 
2 large heads broccoli, finely chopped 
2 cups, frozen peas 
2 handfuls baby spinach 
1 handful fresh parsley 
1 handful watercress, 
1 handful fresh mint 
4 cups water 
Salt and pepper 
Olive oil

Directions

Prepare all your veggies by cutting to desired shape and thickness. 
Crush the garlic cloves. 
Preheat a large saucepan over low-medium heat. 
Add the oil and all the veggies, peas and herbs. 
Season well and cook for 3 minutes. 
Pour in the water and stir well. 
Reduce the heat to low and cook for 5-8 minutes. 
Set aside to cool slightly. Blend until smooth. 
Return the purée to the saucepan for reheating when needed.
teaser: Popeye was so onto it with his spinach! This simple green leaf is one to not miss on the dinner plate.

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Broth
body:
Soul food doesn't have to be heavy, complicated, or meat laden. Enjoy this beautiful broth rich in flavor but light on your digestion. It's a wonderful alternative to traditional comfort foods.

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

2 heads broccoli, cut into big chunks 
3 corn cobs, cut into big chunks 
2 onions, roughly chopped 
6 garlic cloves, smashed 
2 large zucchini, cut into big chunks 
4 medium carrots, cut into big chunks 
3 potatoes, cut into chunks 
250g button mushrooms, whole 
2 leeks, cut into big chunks, green part too 
2 celery sticks, roughly chopped 
100g parsley, roughly chopped 
2 tbsp salt 
1 tsp black pepper 
8 liters water

Directions

Combine all ingredients in a large, 15-litre pot. 
Cook for 3 hours over low heat. 
Allow to rest before serving.
teaser: Enjoy this beautiful broth which is rich in flavor but light on your digestion. It's a wonderful alternative to traditional comfort foods.

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Herb French Toast
body:
Do you miss having French toast? There's something about fresh bread that brings back memories. Whether you are gluten-free, paleo or just want a healthier option to have your bread as your breakfast or snack, you must try this recipe!
Serves: 2

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

4 eggs, whisked 
½ cup parsley, finely chopped 
2 spring onions, finely chopped 
½ cup soy milk 
Salt and pepper 
4 slices brown bread 
Olive oil

Directions

Add the whisked eggs, herbs, and milk to a bowl. 
Whisk to combine and season well. 
Heat a pan on low-to-medium heat and add the olive oil. 
Dip each slice of bread into the egg mixture. 
Allow the bread slices to soak the egg mixture, making sure the slices are evenly coated with the herbs. 
Add the slices to your pan and cook until golden brown.

Note*

Make sure your bread slices have come from the fridge and have not been stored at room temperature.
teaser: Whether you are gluten-free, paleo or just want a healthier option to have your bread as your breakfast or snack, you must try this recipe!

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Gado Gado
body:
Gado gado is one of the well known dishes from Indonesia which usually has slightly boiled, blanched or steamed vegetables, hard-boiled eggs, and boiled potatoes.
Serves: 3

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

4 potatoes, cut into wedges 
1 carrot, cut into large sticks 
1 zucchini, cut into large sticks 
½ head cauliflower, cut into bite-sized pieces 
½ bunch of broccoli, cut into bite-sized pieces 
½ wombok cabbage (also known as Chinese or Napa cabbage), roughly chopped 
4 eggs, boiled and cut into quarters 
300g mung bean shoots 
1 bunch fresh coriander, roughly chopped 
1 bunch thai basil, leaves removed 
1 long red chili, finely chopped

Directions

Steam your potatoes until cooked but not too soft. 
Remove and set aside. 
Steam your carrot, zucchini, cauliflower, and broccoli until al dente. 
Remove and mix with the potatoes. 
Add the rest of the ingredients to the same bowl. 
Season with salt and pepper.

NOT PEANUT SATAY SAUCE
Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

1/2 cup, almond butter 
2 tbsp sesame oil 
2 tbsp grated fresh ginger 
1/2 garlic clove 
1/4 tsp cayenne pepper 
3 tbsp tamari 
1/2 cup water

Directions

Add all ingredients into a blender and blend until smooth. 
Mix in more ginger, tamari, and cayenne if you want a stronger flavor.
teaser: Gado gado is one of the well known dishes from Indonesia which usually has slightly boiled, blanched or steamed vegetables, hard-boiled eggs, and boiled potatoes!

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Green Eggs Breakfast Glory
body:
It's a light and satisfying bowl of breakfast eggs with loads of nourishing greens that will start your day with good nutrition. It will set you up with lots of energy, help you feel fresh and keep nasty bloating away. And when you start your day right, you focus better and make healthier choices all day long.
Serves: 1

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

3 eggs, whisked 
½ zucchini, cut into bite-sized pieces 
3 mushrooms, thinly sliced 
¼ leek, thinly sliced 
3 spring onions, thinly sliced 
½ bunch baby spinach, roughly chopped 
1 tomato 
½ cup sprouts 
Salt and pepper 
Olive oil

Directions

Heat a medium pan over low heat. 
Add the olive oil and all the veggies except the spinach. 
Season well with salt and pepper. 
Cook for 3 minutes and stir the veggies constantly. 
Mix in the spinach stirring constantly. 
Sprinkle with a splash of olive oil once again. 
Add the eggs covering all the veggies. 
Reduce the heat to low and pop the lid on. 
Cook for 1-2 minutes then turn off the heat and allow to rest with the lid on. 
Serve with the tomato and sprouts, olives and more herbs, seasoned well.
teaser: It's a light and satisfying bowl of breakfast eggs with loads of nourishing greens that will start your day with good nutrition!

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Leek Sauce
body:
Discover an amazing recipe using the 'undervalued' vegetable called leek. This recipe for leek sauce is so simple to make and full of nourishing ingredients to give your veggies a boost!
Makes: 750ml of sauce

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)
SAUCE

1 leek, sliced 
1 cup cashews 
5 cups water 
Salt and pepper

VEGGIES

1 small sweet potato, skin on, cut into quarters 
200g beans, roughly chopped 
1 head broccoli, cut into florets 
½ head cauliflower, cut into florets 
10 button mushrooms, whole 
½ cup parsley, roughly chopped 
3 spring onions, roughly chopped

Directions

Combine leek, cashew, and water in a medium-sized pot. 
Bring to a boil over high heat and cook for 8 minutes. 
Turn off the heat and allow to rest for 5 minutes. 
Pour into a blender and blend until creamy and smooth. 
Season well with salt and pepper and set aside. 
Steam the sweet potato. 
Then add the beans, broccoli, cauliflower, button mushrooms, parsley, and spring onions. 
Steam for about 2-4 minutes. 
Shower the veggies with the wonderfully rich leek sauce.
teaser: Discover an amazing recipe using the 'under-valued' vegetable called leek. This recipe for leek sauce is so simple to make and full of nourishing ingredients to give your veggies a boost

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Breakfast Porridge
body:
Take your regular oatmeal to a whole new level of deliciousness and nutrition. Serve with your favorite nut milk and sweetener, and pack with healthy fruit like bananas!
Serves: 4

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

1 litre water 
Fresh ginger, sliced 
1 vanilla pod 
2-inch cinnamon stick 
¼ cup sultanas 
2 cups oats (steel cut) 
Pinch of salt 
3 bananas, sliced

Directions

Combine the first 5 ingredients in a pot. 
Bring to a boil and cook for 3-5 minutes. 
Mix in the oats and salt. 
Stir constantly for 4-6 minutes. 
Add the bananas and cook for 2 more minutes. 
Serve with your favorite nut milk and sweetener.
teaser: Take your regular oatmeal to a whole new level of deliciousness and nutrition. Serve with your favorite nut milk and sweetener, and pack with healthy fruit like bananas!

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Potato Bake
body:
Ever wondered why potato is so good for you? It's rich in essential vitamins and minerals, and can be used for so many dishes!
Serves: 4 large servings

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

10 unpeeled potatoes, thinly sliced 
15 mushrooms, thinly sliced 
3 garlic cloves, roughly chopped 
1 red capsicum, julienned 
1 red chili, deseeded and finely diced 
2 cups cashews 
2 cups water 
1 tbsp paprika 
½ tsp salt 
½ tsp pepper

Directions

Preheat your oven 340 °F (170 °C). 
Combine the cashews and water in a blender and blend until completely smooth and creamy. 
You can use the blades of a food processor to slice your potatoes and mushrooms. 
Mix all the ingredients along with the cashew cream in a large mixing bowl. 
Season with salt and pepper. 
Transfer this mix into a baking tray. 
Sprinkle with extra paprika on top. 
Cover with foil and bake 45 minutes to 1 hour, until fork tender.
teaser: Ever wondered why potato is so good for you? It's rich in essential vitamins and minerals, and can be used for so many dishes!

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Red Rice Salad
body:
Discover just how simple, delicious and nourishing wholefood red rice salad can be!
Serves: 4

SALAD
Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

1 ½ cups raw red rice 
2 cups water 
¼ cup goji berries 
1 long green chili, finely sliced 
3 spring onions, finely sliced 
1 carrot, finely diced 
1 red capsicum, finely diced 
1 cucumber, finely diced 
1 bunch of parsley, roughly chopped 
Salt and pepper

DRESSING
Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

¼ cup soy sauce or tamari 
2 tbsp maple syrup 
1 tbsp apple cider vinegar 
1 tbsp sesame oil 
Salt and pepper 
¼ cup sunflower seeds (topping) 
¼ cup pumpkin seeds (topping)

Directions

Bring rice and water mixture to a boil. 
While rice is cooking, cut vegetables for salad and place in a large bowl. 
Add the hot, cooked rice to the salad and toss well. 
Combine all the dressing ingredients in a bowl and mix well. 
Drizzle over the salad. 
Serve the salad topped with the seeds.
teaser: Discover just how simple, delicious and nourishing wholefood red rice salad can be!

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Satay Veggies
body:
This vegetarian dish is extremely satisfying. Thick, rich and creamy, this sauce makes a great accompaniment to veggies. It's a flavorful way of introducing raw food into your kids' diet!
Serves: 3

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

½ head broccoli, cut into florets 
1 zucchini, cut into bite-sized chunks 
1 carrot, cut into bite-sized chunks 
8 mushrooms, cut into quarters 
1 onion, thinly sliced 
2 lemongrass stalks, finely sliced 
1 bunch of fresh coriander, roughly chopped 
3 cups, mung bean shoots 
3 spring onions

SATAY SAUCE
Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

1 cup, almond butter 
3 tbsp sesame oil 
1-2 tbsp maple syrup or honey 
4 tbsp grated fresh ginger 
¼ tsp cayenne pepper 
4 tbsp soy sauce or tamari 
1 ½ cups, water 
Salt and pepper

Directions

Steam all the veggies and the lemongrass (leaving out the fresh herbs, spring onions, and sprouts). 
When just cooked, transfer into a bowl along with the herbs, onions, and sprouts. 
Add all the satay ingredients to a blender and blend until completely smooth and creamy. 
Serve with the veggies.
teaser: Thick, rich and creamy, this sauce makes a great accompaniment to veggies. It's a flavorful way of introducing raw food into your kids' diet!

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Soba Noodle Warm Fruity Salad
body:
Soba noodles are traditionally made with buckwheat - a nutritious seed packed full of fiber, magnesium, lysine and amino acids. But be sure to check the packet labels. Many brands supplement their buckwheat noodles with wheat flour. So, if you want to be gluten-free make sure you choose 100% buckwheat soba..
Serves: 4

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)
SOBA OR BUCKWHEAT NOODLES

1 packet buckwheat noodles 
1 eggplant, cut into bite-sized pieces 
1 mango, chopped into bite-sized pieces 
1 garlic clove, minced 
½ red onion, sliced into small dice 
¼ cup coriander leaves 
¼ cup parsley leaves 
1 spring onion, finely chopped 
¼ cup basil 
Coconut oil 
Salt and pepper 
Cashews, nuts or anything crunchy for garnish

DRESSING

1 ½ tsp sesame oil 
2 tbsp water 
2 tbsp soy sauce or tamari 
2 tbsp maple syrup 
2 tsp minced ginger

Directions

Cook your noodles, drain well, rinse with water and set aside. 
Prepare your dressing by mixing all the ingredients well. Set aside. 
Prepare ginger, garlic, onion, coriander leaves, parsley leaves, spring onion and basil. 
Slice your mango. 
Heat a wok over medium heat, add a splash of coconut oil and the eggplant. 
Season well with salt and pepper. 
Cook until slightly golden brown (if you need to, it is okay to add more oil). 
When cooked, remove and transfer to a bowl. Add all the remaining ingredients into the bowl. 
Season well and mix with your hands. 
Enjoy it knowing you have this amazing moment to eat. 
Drizzle with the dressing, sprinkle with the nuts and serve.
teaser: This healthy salad has a great crunch and lots of refreshing flavors!

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Spicy Eggplants
body:
Eggplants are the ultimate brain food! That bright purple skin isn't just pretty, it contains anthocyanin phytonutrients, a fancy name for a powerful antioxidant. This has been shown to fight against those nasty free radicals and protect the lipids in brain cell membranes. So feed your brain with this recipe.
Serves: 4

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

6 long japanese eggplants, cut lengthwise 
3 long red chilies, roughly chopped 
4 garlic cloves, roughly chopped 
2 shallots, roughly chopped 
6 roma tomatoes, roughly chopped 
3 kaffir lime leaves 
Salt and pepper 
Coconut oil

Directions

Add some coconut oil and your eggplants to a large pan on medium heat. 
Cook until quite soft and cooked all the way through. They should be slightly golden brown. 
Remove and set aside. 
In the same pan on medium heat, add a splash of coconut oil, and the chilies, garlic, shallots, salt and pepper. 
Sauté for 5 minutes. 
Turning up the heat to high, add your tomatoes and kaffir lime leaves. 
Stir constantly and cook for 5 minutes. 
Turn off the heat allowing it to rest for 5 minutes. 
Blend in your blender until smooth. 
Combine the eggplants and sauce together in the pan and reheat for 4-5 minutes.
teaser: Eggplants are the ultimate brain food! So feed your brain with this recipe.

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Toggie Sprouts
body:
An increase in fiber helps keep you 'regular' + cleans your insides! So indulge in this quick but very nourishing Toggie sprouts recipe!
Serves: 2

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

¼ cabbage, thinly sliced 
3 garlic cloves, roughly chopped 
200g mushrooms 
500g mung bean shoots 
1 packet tempeh, diced into bite-sized pieces 
1 long red chili, roughly chopped 
½ onion, finely diced 
1 red capsicum, thinly diced

Directions

Arrange all of the ingredients nicely into a steamer. 
Steam for 6 minutes. 
Serve this with salad greens.

DRESSING
Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

1 tbsp sesame seed oil 
2 tbsp soy sauce 
1 tbsp maple syrup 
1 tbsp ginger, grated

Directions

Mix the all dressing ingredients well.
teaser: An increase in fiber helps keep you ‘regular’ + cleans your insides! So indulge in this quick but very nourishing Toggie sprouts recipe!

seriesTitle: Whole Food Love with Chef Cynthia Louise
title: Green Breakfast Bowl
body:
Some worry that vegetarian and vegan diets might lack sufficient protein. What most people do not know is that sprouts can contain up to 35 percent protein. Adding sprouts to your diet will give you the necessary protein intake required by your body minus the fat, cholesterol, and calories that typically come with animal products.
Serves: 2

Ingredients
(use organic where possible)

1 cup broccoli florets 
¼ zucchini, chopped into half rounds 
6 button mushrooms, whole 
1 small leek, sliced 
1 handful spinach 
3 tbsp udo's oil, divided use 
¼ cup apple cider vinegar 
¼ cup peas 
½ avocado 
1 cup shredded cabbage 
¼ cup parsley, roughly chopped 
1 cup living sprouts (optional) 
2 tbsp hemp seeds (optional) 
Olives 
Salt and pepper

Directions

Steam the broccoli and zucchini in a steamer until just tender. 
Turn the heat off and add the spinach. 
Transfer to a bowl and toss with 2 tablespoons of oil. 
Season well with salt and pepper. 
Add all the remaining ingredients, arranging them nicely on a large plate and seasoning well. 
In a small bowl, mix the vinegar and the remaining tablespoon of oil. 
Set aside ready to pour it over your green bowl of goodness. 
Top with living sprouts and hemp seeds, if desired. 
Serve and enjoy!
teaser: Adding sprouts to your diet will give you the necessary protein intake required by your body minus the fat, cholesterol, and calories that typically come with animal products!
